item.title: Beatification Brings Opus Dei Into the Open
item.description: The beatification Mass for a former leader of Opus Dei is an unusually public show of force for the movement, one of the most powerful and discreet in Catholicism.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Priests preparing in Madrid for the beatification Mass for Álvaro del Portillo of Opus Dei. Some 200,000 people are expected.

item.title: 3 Nations Offer Limited Support To Attack on ISIS
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron faced questions from lawmakers over the air campaign’s scope and objectives, but he ultimately won an overwhelming mandate for action.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Royal Air Force Tornado warplanes preparing to land at a British base in Cyprus last month.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Greek Politician Willing to Face the People
item.description: Rena Dourou’s election as prefect of Athens represents the biggest victory so far for the left-wing Syriza Party.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and DIMITRIS BOUNIAS
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: “People were amazed to see me. They had never met a politician. They were touching me, saying, ‘You are Rena Dourou?’”

item.title: Pro-Democracy Students Are Arrested in Hong Kong
item.description: Student protests near the government headquarters ended in confrontation and arrests, with plans for a larger sit-in next week.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Chan Kin-man, left, and Benny Tai, co-founders of the Occupy Central movement, introduced a civil-disobedience manual at a news conference in Hong Kong on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Considers a No-Fly Zone to Protect Civilians From Airstrikes by Syria
item.description: The administration is open to establishing a buffer zone along the Turkish-Syrian border, where tens of thousands of Syrians have sought refuge.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Mexico Holds 8 in Army in Inquiry of 22 Deaths
item.description: The arrests represent a reversal for officials who initially described the June encounter as a shootout.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Open Source: Video Shows Protester Pleading With Rouhani to Free Iranian Woman Jailed for Visit to Sports Arena
item.description: An Iranian student at Yale pressed Iran’s president this week to free a woman detained in Tehran “only for the act of trying to watch volleyball.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Facing Militants With Supplies Dwindling, Iraqi Soldiers Took to Phones
item.description: Soldiers’ accounts of a battle this week exposed some of the glaring weaknesses of the Iraqi Army as it tries to counter Islamic State militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: As Catalonia Weighs Independence From Spain, Leader Seizes Spotlight
item.description: The legal problems of Mr. Jordi Pujol, a former leader of the Convergence party, have cast a shadow over the party’s push for independence from Spain.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Refugee Flow to Industrialized Nations Is Poised for a 20-Year High
item.description: More than 330,700 people applied for asylum in 44 countries in Europe, North America and parts of the Asia-Pacific region in the first half of the year, a U.N. agency reported.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: In London, Houseboats Offer Alternative to High Rent, but New Problems Emerge
item.description: As rents skyrocket, canal homes are proliferating, putting berths at a premium and stretching the existing support system.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGI KANTCHEV

item.title: Digital War Takes Shape On Websites Over ISIS
item.description: A government team’s striking video and other postings are being disseminated through Twitter and Facebook to counter ISIS’s skillful online campaigns.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: Obama Urges Global Effort To Help Prevent Epidemics
item.description: The president spoke at a White House meeting of more than 40 health ministers, imploring them to provide better services to prevent deadly outbreaks like Ebola.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Palestinian Leader Urges U.N. to Press for Deadline to End Israeli Occupation
item.description: Addressing the General Assembly, the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, criticized Israel but did not offer his own time frame for an Israeli withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Obama Can Still Earn His Nobel
item.description: The leader who didn’t have a strategy for dealing with Islamic State nihilists a few weeks ago just dropped an idea bomb on the rest of the world.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIMOTHY EGAN

item.title: A Jab at Indonesia’s President-Elect as Parliament Curbs Local Voting
item.description: The departing Indonesian Parliament passed a law on Friday eliminating the popular vote for mayors, district chiefs and governors.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Joko Widodo, the Indonesian president-elect, center, leaving a swearing-in ceremony for local legislators in Jakarta on Friday.

item.title: Under Pact, Russians To Give Gas To Ukraine
item.description: The agreement, brokered by European officials, aims to ensure gas flows over the coming six months, despite a dispute between Moscow and Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and ALISON SMALE

item.title: Ebola Doctor Shortage Eases as Volunteers Step Forward
item.description: Even with the volunteers, experts say, there will be a long gap before hospitals can be fully staffed to care for the growing numbers of Ebola patients.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Local health workers with members of Doctors Without Borders at a hospital in Conakry, Guinea on Thursday. More foreign doctors and nurses are volunteering, but a gap remains.

item.title: ISIS Lieutenant Emerges From Australian Red-Light District
item.description: A phone call said to have been made by Mohammad Ali Baryalei, a former Sydney bouncer who is now a leader in the Islamic State, set off a counterterrorism crackdown in Australia.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The funeral on Friday of an 18-year-old man who stabbed two counterterrorism officers outside Melbourne, Australia, earlier this month before one of the officers shot and killed him. The police described the man as a “known terror suspect” who had been seen carrying an Islamic State flag at a local shopping center.

item.title: India and China Step Back From Standoff in Kashmir
item.description: The two countries agreed to begin withdrawing troops in Ladakh to the positions they were in at the beginning of September.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: University of Chicago’s Relations With Confucius Institute Sour
item.description: The University of Chicago has suspended negotiations to renew its agreement with the Confucius Institute, a global network of Chinese government-affiliated language and culture centers.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The institutes are named for the ancient sage Confucius, memorialized in a statue at Qingdao University, Shandong Province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Anson Chan on Political Compromise in Hong Kong
item.description: One of the most vocal and articulate supporters of greater democracy in Hong Kong, the former Chief Secretary Anson Chan, is trying to find room to compromise with the pro-Beijing camp on electing the top leader.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Students protesting Beijing's restrictive election framework outside the Hong Kong government offices.

item.title: North Korea Reveals Leader Is ‘Not Feeling Well’
item.description: In a rare revelation about the top leader’s health, North’s Central TV showed Mr. Kim walking with a limp while visiting a factory.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un in an undated picture released by the Korean Central News Agency. This summer, Mr. Kim had been seen on video walking with a limp.

item.title: Australia Alarms Rights Groups With Deal to Resettle Refugees in Cambodia
item.description: In an agreement with Cambodia, asylum seekers in Australia’s offshore centers could voluntarily relocate to one of the poorest countries in Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Cambodian police officers blocked protesters outside the Australian Embassy in Phnom Penh before the signing on Friday.

item.title: 4 Children Stabbed to Death in Southern China
item.description: The children were walking to school in Guangxi Province when a man driving a motorized pedicab chased them down with a knife, state media reported.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
